item.title: New York Times Connections Hints and Answers for #385 June 30, 2024
item.description:
Connections is back with another mind-boggling selection of seemingly random words to put into groups. There is only one possible answer, and it can be a huge challenge to get to it before you run out of tries.

If you are already familiar with how to play Connections but are looking for help with this puzzle specifically, you can find all sorts of helpful tips in the article below. In it, you'll see general puzzle hints, clues to the categories, spoilers, and even the whole answer if you want to see it.

Words in the NYT Connections Puzzle #385 for June 30, 2024

The Connections puzzle for today contains the words: Ash, Electric, Saw, Jet, Gas, Chestnut, Filter, Gum, Ebony, Maxim, Wood, Heater, Pump, Cherry, Charcoal, and Adage.

Hints for the NYT Connections Puzzle

Since this mobile game similar to Wordle is pretty hard today, you might be in need of a push in the right direction. You can find all sorts of hints in the expandable sections below to help you out.

Some General Hints for the Whole Connections Puzzle

Yellow NYT Connections Category Hints

Yellow Connections Category Answer

Yellow Connections Category Answer and All Four Words

Green NYT Connections Category Hints

Green Connections Category Answer

Green Connections Category Answer and All Four Words

Blue NYT Connections Category Hints

Blue Connections Category Answer

Blue Connections Category Answer and All Four Words

Purple NYT Connections Category Hints

Purple Connections Category Answer

Purple Connections Category Answer and All Four Words

Answers for Today's NYT Connections #385 for June 30, 2024

The answer to the New York Times Games Connections is located in the expandable section below. Click the Read More button to see all four categories and the words from each one.

Want to play? Check out the New York Times Games Connections website available on almost any device with a browser.

item.title: New York Times Strands Hints and Answers for June 30, 2024
item.description:
Strands has a whole new 6x8 letter grid to find a bunch of themed words inside. This word-search puzzle might seem simple at first blush, but it can get challenging to figure out the theme and what words could fit both in the theme and the letter grid.

If you are already familiar with the rules of Strands , but you need help with today's puzzle, you can find it below. This article contains general hints, spoilers, the answer, and an explanation of the theme as well.

The NYT Games Strands Puzzle #119 for June 30, 2024

The Strands puzzle for today has the clue Cut and Color . There are seven items to find: one Spangram category and six themed words inside the letter grid.

New York Times Games Strands Clues

There are three expandable sections below, and each one contains a single hint for this challenging puzzle game. None of them will spoil any of the words in the puzzle; they are designed to help you figure out the theme for today instead.

General Hint 1

General Hint 2

General Hint 3

Spoilers for Two of the Words in Today's Strands

There are two spoiled words below for this innovative puzzle game. There is only one word in each expandable section, both of them covered to make sure you don't spoil too much for yourself by scrolling.

Spoiler 1

Spoiler 2

The Answer to Today's New York Times Games Strands

The answer to this New York Times Games puzzle is in the section below. You can see the filled-out puzzle with all the words and their locations in the grid.

Today's Strands Explained

The full explanation for how the themed words and clue fit together. Click the Read More button below to see it.

Want to play? Check out the New York Times Games Strands website available on almost any device with a browser.

item.title: Disney Dreamlight Valley: A Daily Regime Walkthrough
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Make Vegetarian Pizza
  • Gather Gems
  • Go Back to Mulan's Realm
  • Brew Some Tea

Once you've unlocked both Mulan and Mushu in Disney Dreamlight Valley , you will be able to give them items and level them up. When you reach Level Two with Mulan, you will unlock her first friendship quest. As Mulan tries to get settled in Dreamlight Valley, she needs help setting up a training routine. While this quest is pretty standard in terms of friendship quest objectives, it does take some time to complete due to the second step. Here is how to complete A Daily Regime in Disney Dreamlight Valley .

Make Vegetarian Pizza

For the first part of this quest, you will have to make two Vegetarian Pizzas. Mulan gives you the recipe, even if you have already learned it. To make both Vegetarian Pizzas, you will need to gather two carrots, two cheeses, two wheat, and two tomatoes. Everything can be grown except for the cheese which is purchased from Remy at his restaurant.

Gather Gems

After you give Mulan the pizzas, she will have a new task that is part of her training routine. You will need to gather gems from mining. To be specific, you must obtain three Topaz, four Aquamarine, six Garnet, and six Peridot. Unfortunately, gems you've already acquired do not count, so you will be starting from scratch.

It is unclear if this is a bug or not, but gems that are spawned by a companion with the mining role don't seem to count for this quest. To make matters worse, having a companion with you seems to also make any gem you obtain not count. If either of these situations are bugs that end up getting fixed later, this guide will be updated.

Shiny versions of gems also don't count for this quest, so if you pick up a gem and the quest objective doesn't update, that is why.

After you have finally gathered all of the gems, find Mulan and talk to her. You don't need to give her the gems, so once you've talked to her you can just sell them if you want.

Go Back to Mulan's Realm

For the next step, Mulan wants you to bring some crates of tea back from her realm. Unfortunately she is unable to return their as she will lose her memories, so that means you have to go in her stead. The Crate of Jasmine Tea is to the left of the crafting station inside the camp.

The Oolong Tea is to the right of the kiln and shelves where the statues appeared during the quest to unlock both Mushu and Mulan.

Finally, the Chrysanthemum Tea is to the right of where you found the Oolong Tea.

After finding all three, head back to Mulan. When you give her the crates, she gets the idea to make a tea stall where all the villagers can go and get some tea. Pick a spot in Dreamlight Valley, place it, and then talk to Mulan once again.

Brew Some Tea

To get things started, Mulan give you some recipes for various kinds of tea and a recipe for biscuits. The ingredients for everything is as follows:

Oolong Tea:

  • Oolong Tea Leaf
  • Raspberry

Jasmine Tea:

  • Jasmine Tea Leaf
  • Sugarcane

Chrysanthemum Tea:

  • Chrysanthemum Tea Leaf
  • Blueberry

Biscuit:

  • Wheat
  • Sugarcane
  • Butter

All the tea leaves needed can be acquired from Mulan's tea stall. The Sugarcane and Wheat can be grown while the Blueberry and Raspberry can be gathered. After you make the tea and the biscuits, bring them to Mulan. Smelling the tea will remind her of the parties she used to throw before the Forgetting. Find Scrooge, Mirabel, and Merlin and invite them over for tea.

With the guests all invited, head to Mulan's house and go inside. Talk to Mulan and then talk to the other guests. Mulan will tell you what everyone's favorite tea is. When talking to the guests, they will ask you what tea they should have next. It doesn't matter which option you choose for them, as once you've talked to them and talked to Mulan one last time you will have completed this quest.

item.title: A Future Starfield Expansion Could Fill Out its Universe by Following Fallout's Lead
item.description:
Starfield 's Shattered Space expansion is set for a release window of Fall 2024. The massive scale of the title in terms of its exploration perfectly compliments post-launch expansions such as this, with there being an immense amount of narrative leeway to expand the game's lore.

The Shattered Space expansion for Starfield recently got some attention at the Xbox Games Showcase, with its time at the presentation confirming the major involved factions and locations of the DLC. While Shattered Space smartly places more emphasis on one of the most underused pre-existing factions in Starfield , the title could easily take a page out of Fallout 's book for its future expansions. In particular, new major groups and factions in Fallout have consistently been added to the franchise over the years, and Starfield could use its scope to do the same thing through future DLCs.

Starfield Should Use Future Expansions to Introduce New Intergalactic Groups

Despite a lot of the pre-release marketing for Starfield focusing on its massive scale, there are only five major factions that populate its vast game world. Of course, implementing even more major factions into the base game may have risked bloating the side content of Starfield , but there is still clear room for more stories to be told within the franchise.

While most of these five pre-existing factions get a fair amount of development and story content in Starfield , many fans felt that the mysterious and hyper-religious House Va'ruun did not get nearly enough attention in the game. The upcoming Shattered Space expansion for Starfield has clearly taken these criticisms on board, with House Va'ruun being at the center of the upcoming story.

Despite not getting much love in the base game of Starfield , House Va'ruun is arguably the game's most interesting faction, with its members worshiping a deity known as the Great Serpent. The isolation and deep devotion of House Va'ruun is a perfect way to instill mystery in Starfield 's setting, with the game clearly having all the tools necessary to craft even more fascinating factions in the future.

Starfield's Many Locations Can Easily Give Way to New Factions

It has already been confirmed that Starfield will receive at least one more major expansion following the release of Shattered Space, with Bethesda clearly believing that there is still a lot of unexplored narrative potential for the title. While it only seems fair that Shattered Space should finally elaborate on House Va'ruun, subsequent expansions could easily introduce brand-new factions, much like how Fallout has over the years.

Fallout 's nuclear wastelands are much smaller than the huge portion of outer space that Starfield explores, yet the former has always found ways to evolve its major groups in logical ways.

While the likes of the Brotherhood of Steel have appeared in the IP for quite some time, fan-favorite titles like Fallout New Vegas owed a lot of their success to the new groups they explored, with FNV famously introducing factions like Caesar's Legion. These factions are often deeply tied to the different areas that Fallout explores, with Fallout 4 's Boston setting giving way to the Minutemen faction, which is inspired by Minutemen of New England in the Revolutionary era.

With Starfield having so many star systems and planets to explore, the title is in no shortage of locations that can potentially be expanded to inspire factions in future DLCs for the game. Locational factions have been a huge part of Fallout 's continued success and expanded lore over the years, and Bethesda should definitely consider transferring this ethos to its most recent release to give more justification for Starfield 's massive size through any future DLCs.

item.title: 6 Best SNES RPG Side Quests
item.description:
Side quests are often associated with 3D RPGs in a post-PS1 world. Its easy to see why, since the 3D era helped evolve the storytelling of games. When discussing the best side quests in gaming, players often refer to expansive worlds such as those in Skyrim or The Witcher 3, which have giant open-world and hundreds of quests to take on. However, side quests did not originate in the 3D era.

Some of the best RPGs of the SNES era have side quests that stack up next to entries in The Elder Scrolls or Fallout franchises. Lets take a look at some cool side quests in games on the SNES, which contribute to their status as great SNES RPGs overall.

6 Recruiting Magus

Chrono Trigger

A good portion of Chrono Trigger sets up Magus as the big bad of the game. After defeating him, he disappears into the void once he manages to summon Lavos. Lavos then becomes the boss whom Crono and the others have to stop.

Near the end of the game, players can start to hear rumors about Magus from townsfolk across timelines. If players then travel to the North Cape in 12,000 B.C., they can find Magus once again. He will challenge the party to a fight, and if players do cross swords with him, he will die. If players instead walk away, he will follow Crono and join the party. Its worth sparing Magus because it gives a former villain a redemption arc, not to mention the fact that he is incredibly strong.

5 Gotta Tame Em All!

Dragon Quest 5: Hand of the Heavenly Bride

Dragon Quest 5: Hand of the Heavenly Bride is the first game in the Dragon Quest series to focus on one party member who fills up his party roster with monsters. After battle, players have a chance to befriend monsters from Slimes to Drackies. It was like Pokemon before that franchise blew up. There are about forty in the SNES version, and the roster was expanded in later releases.

The first time North America got to play it, for example, was on the DS. This version did offer some monster upgrades, but before this, there was a fan patch for the original version. This included a meta-side quest in the game to collect all the monsters. Its not a direct side quest with a big reward at the end, but getting through the game with this horde of monsters did feel like an accomplishment.

4 Fighting Bahamut

Final Fantasy 4

Final Fantasy 4 has a lot of great side quests in it, like most entries in the Final Fantasy series. One of the most memorable and challenging revolves around Bahamut. The king of dragons appeared in the first game, but became a Summon in Final Fantasy 3, which was also the first game to feature that type of class.

In Final Fantasy 4 , Bahamut resides on the moon in the aptly titled Cave of Bahamut. Players have to defeat it, which is not easy as Bahamut hits hard. Afterward, it will become a Summon for Rydia, and will boost the partys power considerably. It might be the hardest boss fight against Bahamut from any Final Fantasy game, but it all ultimately depends on how much players grind EXP.

3 Saving Shadow

Final Fantasy 6

Shadow is a ninja who is an on-again-off-again party member in Final Fantasy 6 . Players can eventually recruit him, but there are many steps. First, players have to make sure and wait for him on the floating continent before the world ends. Then, in the World of Ruin, players should go to the Cave on the Veldt, which will end with a boss fight against the Behemoth King.

Once Shadow is saved, he will depart for the Dragon's Neck Coliseum, wherein players will have to get lucky in their battle to defeat and recruit him. Its worth the hassle, as Shadow is the coolest character in the game, from his move set to his whistle theme to his trusty dog Interceptor.

2 Powering Up The Master Sword

The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past

The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past is not a classic RPG with EXP, but this action-adventure epic has plenty of RPG elements, like a health system and magic, as well as one of the most epic quests in the Zelda series. After obtaining the Master Sword and traveling to the Dark World, players can find the Dwarven Smiths brother from Kakariko Village. In the Dark World, he is a frog and lost in a maze of confusion.

When led back to the Light World via the Magic Mirror, the two brothers will temper the Master Sword for Link. This changes it to an orange hue. The sword can then be upgraded a second time via the Cursed Fairy in the pyramid-like temple, which changes its color to yellow. This is the final sword in the game, and both of these upgrades are optional.

1 Fighting Culex

Super Mario RPG: Legend of the Seven Stars

Super Mario RPG: Legend of the Seven Stars features tons of Easter Eggs, with sources ranging from other Mario games to Square Enix titles. The biggest Easter Egg of all is Culex, who is framed as an interdimensional being that appears to be from a Final Fantasy game. While Culex is an original creation, it does use Crystals as weapons and has the boss music from Final Fantasy 4 .

To fight him, players must first obtain the Shiny Stone in Moleville by buying fireworks and then trading with a little girl. The Shiny Stone can then open the locked door in Monstro Town, which leads to the Culex fight. In addition to the boss being memorable, the reward after is great. The Quartz Charm can halve damage, increase attacks by 50%, and prevent mortal blows.
